bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to the Surgeon General, September 9, 1902

div1.p: Carroll requests admission into the Medical Corps of the Army. He gives a brief summary of his career as a non-commissioned officer and a contract surgeon, and his terms at medical school. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to the Surgeon General, September 9, 1902
div1.opener:
All communications to this Office should be addressed “To the Surgeon General, U. S. Army, Washington, D. C.”
Subject:
Surgeon General's Office,
U. S. Army Medical Museum and Library,
Corner 7th and B Streets SW.,
Washington, September 9th 1902.
To the
Surgeon General U. S. Army,
Washington, D.C.
Through Major Walter Reed, Surgeon U. S. A.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to request
that I may be granted authority to
appear before the examining board
now in session in this city, as a
candidate for admission to the
Medical Corps of the Army.

I am forty-eight years of age
and a citizen of the United States.
My service has been continuous since
January 1874, twenty-four years as
a non-commissioned officer (fourteen
2.
of them in the capacity of hospital
steward, and four years as a con-
tract surgeon, the whole, I believe,
with a clear record. I have the
honor to have been a member of
the Army Yellow Fever Board, appointed
by Par. 34, S.O. "122, A.G.O., May 24, 1900.

I am a graduate of the University
of Maryland, (1891,) after two courses
at that school and one at the University
of the City of New York. Since 1893 my
work has been confined to bacteriology
and pathology, after taking special
courses in those branches at the Johns
Hopkins post-graduate school.

With twenty-four year's service
to my credit, should I be granted
authority to appear before the board
and be so fortunate as to pass it, I
3.
would still have sixteen years to
serve before reaching the age of sixty-
four, or completing the forty years
of service necessary to render me
eligible for retirement.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully,
your obedient servant, James Carroll Contract Surgeon U. S. Army.
